column1: #Text=For Antonio 's brother , see Piero del Pollaiolo .
#Text=Antonio del Pollaiuolo ( UK : /ˌpɒlaɪˈwoʊloʊ/ POL-eye-WOH-loh , [ 1 ] US : /ˌpoʊl-/ POHL- , [ 2 ]

#Text=Italian : [ anˈtɔːnjo del pollaˈjwɔːlo ] ; 17 January 1429/1433 – 4 February 1498 ) , also known as Antonio di Jacopo Pollaiuolo or Antonio Pollaiuolo ( also spelled Pollaiolo ) , was an Italian painter , sculptor , engraver and goldsmith during the Italian Renaissance .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Tobias and the Angel , Antonio del Pollaiolo
#Text=He was born in Florence .
#Text=His brother , Piero , was also an artist , and the two frequently worked together .
#Text=Their work shows both classical influences and an interest in human anatomy ; reportedly , the brothers carried out dissections to improve their knowledge of the subject .
#Text=They took their nickname from the trade of their father , who in fact sold poultry ( pollaio meaning " hen coop " in Italian ) .
#Text=Antonio 's first studies of goldsmithing and metalworking were under either his father or Andrea del Castagno : the latter probably taught him also in painting .
#Text=Other sources relate that he worked in the Florence workshop of Bartoluccio di Michele , where Lorenzo Ghiberti also received his training . [ 3 ]
#Text=During this time , he also took an interest in engraving .
#Text=Some of Pollaiuolo 's painting exhibits strong brutality , of which the characteristics can be studied in his portrayal of Saint Sebastian , [ 4 ]
#Text=painted in 1473 – 1475 for the Pucci Chapel of the SS . Annunziata of Florence .
#Text=However , in contrast , his female portraits exhibit a calmness and a meticulous attention to detail of fashion , as was the norm in late 15th century portraiture .
#Text=He achieved his greatest successes as a sculptor and metal-worker .
#Text=The exact ascription of his works is doubtful , as his brother Piero did much in collaboration with him . [ 4 ]

#Text=The fifteenth-century addition of the infant twins Romulus and Remus to an existing bronze sculpture of the Ancient Roman mythological she-wolf who nursed them has been attributed by some to him . [ 5 ]

#Text=He only produced one surviving engraving , the Battle of the Nude Men , but both in its size and sophistication this took the Italian print to new levels , and remains one of the most famous prints of the Renaissance .

#Text=In 1484 Antonio took up his residence in Rome , where he executed the tomb of Pope Sixtus IV , now in the Museum of St. Peter 's ( finished in 1493 ) , a composition in which he again manifested the quality of exaggeration in the anatomical features of the figures .
#Text=In 1496 he went to Florence in order to put the finishing touches to the work already begun in the sacristy of Santo Spirito .

#Text=He died in Rome as a rich man , having just finished his mausoleum of Pope Innocent VIII , also in St. Peter 's , and was buried in the church of San Pietro in Vincoli , where a monument was raised to him near that of his brother . [ 4 ]

#Text=His main contribution to Florentine painting lay in his analysis of the human body in movement or under conditions of strain , but he is also important for his pioneering interest in landscape .
#Text=His students included Sandro Botticelli .
